control-flow-story.text: The Linear Train. Without control flow, programs run like a train on tracks—straight through from start to finish. Step one, step two, step three, done. No choices, no variety.
The Video Game Crossroads. Now imagine a video game. When you reach a crossroads, the game doesn't randomly pick—it decides based on your input. Did you press left? Go left. Press right? Go right.
Control Flow. This decision-making power is called control flow. It's the lightning that guides your program's path, letting it think, react, and choose different routes.
Branching Paths. With control flow, your program can branch into different paths. Like a tree growing multiple branches, each condition creates a new possible direction.
The Power of Repetition. Control flow also lets programs repeat actions. Instead of writing the same code a hundred times, you tell it: do this until I say stop!
Smart Programs. Together, branching and repetition transform simple scripts into intelligent programs. Your code can now think, choose, and work tirelessly!

decisions-story.text: Yes or No Questions. Every decision in programming is a yes-or-no question. Is this true? Is that false? Based on the answer, the program takes different paths.
Comparison Operators. To ask these questions, we use comparison operators. Is this equal to that? Is this greater than that? Each comparison returns true or false.
The If Statement. The 'if' statement is the gatekeeper. It checks a condition and says: if this is true, run this code. Otherwise, skip it entirely.
Elif and Else. What if you have multiple conditions? Use 'elif' for additional checks, and 'else' as a catch-all. Python checks from top to bottom—first match wins!
Indentation Matters. Python uses indentation to know which code belongs to which condition. Always use four spaces! It's not just style—it's how Python understands your logic.
The Power of Decisions. Now your programs can react! Check ages, validate passwords, respond to user input—every interactive program relies on these simple yes-or-no decisions.

loops-story.text: The Repetition Problem. What if you need to do something ten times? A hundred times? A million? You don't write the same code over and over—that would be madness!
Enter the Loop. A loop is your solution. Write the code once, tell the computer how many times to repeat it, and watch it work. Efficient and elegant!
The For Loop. The 'for' loop is perfect when you know how many times to repeat. For each item in this list, or for each number in this range, do this action.
Range: Your Number Generator. Python's range function generates numbers for you. Range of one to six gives you one, two, three, four, five. It stops before the end number!
The While Loop. When you don't know how many times to repeat, use 'while'. It keeps going as long as a condition is true—like asking until you get the right answer.
Loop Control. Use 'break' to exit a loop early, and 'continue' to skip to the next iteration. You're in control of when the repetition stops!
